description:
Candidatus Hamiltonella endosymbiont of Tuberolachnus salignus is a bacterial endosymbiont found within the aphid species Tuberolachnus salignus, commonly known as the giant willow aphid. This endosymbiont is a member of the Gammaproteobacteria class and is classified as a "Candidatus" species, meaning it has not been fully characterized and cultured in a laboratory setting.

The Candidatus Hamiltonella endosymbiont resides within the body of the T. salignus aphid, typically in specialized cells called bacteriocytes. This endosymbiotic relationship is believed to provide various benefits to the host aphid, such as improved nutrient acquisition, protection against pathogens, and enhanced environmental adaptation.

While the exact metabolic capabilities and genetic makeup of this endosymbiont are not fully understood, studies have suggested that it may play a role in the aphid's ability to thrive on willow plants, which are its primary host. The presence and diversity of this endosymbiont within different populations of T. salignus aphids are areas of ongoing research.
